qas.question: According to Schopenhauer, to what can the ideal be attributed?
What did Schopenhauer believe we were restricted to?
What did Schopenhauer believe were the only things we could know?
What type of knowledge did Schopenhauer believe the ideal to be?

plausible_answers.text: Sketch of a History of the Doctrine of the Ideal and the Real

qas.question: What essay is in Schopenhauer's second volume?
How are external objects known directly?
Schopenhauer said the ideal was not what type of knowledge?

context: In the first volume of his Parerga and Paralipomena, <a0_0>Schopenhauer<a0_0/> wrote his "<b5_0>Sketch of a History of the Doctrine of the Ideal and the Real<b5_0/>". He defined the ideal as being mental pictures that constitute <a4_0><b8_0><b9_0>subjective<b9_0/><a4_0/> knowledge<b8_0/>. The ideal, for him, is what can be attributed to <a1_0>our own minds<a1_0/>. The images in our head are what comprise the ideal. Schopenhauer emphasized that we are restricted to <a2_0><b6_0>our own consciousness<b6_0/><a2_0/>. The world that appears is only a representation or mental picture of objects. We directly and immediately know only <a3_0>representations<a3_0/>. All objects that are external to the mind are known indirectly through the <b7_0>mediation of our mind<b7_0/>. He offered a history of the concept of the "ideal" as "ideational" or "existing in the mind as an image".
